subject: History
title: The Roots of the Scramble for Africa
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Roots of the Scramble for Africa usable.

hook.text: European exploration of Africa's interior came shockingly late‚Äîmost of the continent was unknown until the 1800s.

buildup.text: Malaria, hostile terrain, and powerful African kingdoms kept Europeans confined to coastal trading posts.

discovery.text: Quinine's discovery as a malaria treatment in the 1820s suddenly made inland exploration survivable.

twist.text: Explorers like Livingstone and Stanley were treated as heroes. Their maps became blueprints for conquest.

climax.text: By 1884, European powers carved Africa into colonies at the Berlin Conference‚Äîwithout a single African present.

punchline.text: A malaria pill enabled the colonization of a continent.

quiz.question: What medical breakthrough enabled European exploration of Africa's interior?
options: Quinine as a treatment for malaria
